title: Analysis of Waxy Plant Surface on Rudbeckia fulgida Leaf
content: Cuticular waxes on the surface of plant leaves serve multiple functions: (1) prevention from drying out, (2) protection from ultraviolet radiation and microbial pathogens, and (3) retention and penetration of agriculturally important chemicals. Such wax layers are known to comprised of long carbon chain fatty acids and other organic compounds which incorporate carbonyl functional groups [1]. Waxes are commonly used in the food industry as coatings to help retain moisture and prevent spoilage and they also have applications in many other areas such as cosmetics, pharmaceutical, textiles, lubricants, automobiles, and furniture [2].
